section.name: Beige-Accounting on Android.
section.p:
This is same WEB application based on embedded A-Jetty for Android. Bob decided to try this application on his Android smartphone. He installed Google Chrome. Then he installed the last APK Beige Accounting from central Maven repository https://search.maven.org/#search%7Cga%7C1%7Cg%3A%22org.beigesoft%22. He started it then push button "Start" to start A-Jetty server. Then he push button "http://localhost:8080", chrome browser will be opened this address. If you can't set chrome as default browser, then type this address by hand in it (these screenshots from Samsung DUOS Android 4.2.2):
Start menu is:
He uploaded database as bobspizza.sqlite into Google Drive from his notebook then downloaded it on smartphone then moved it into "BeigeAccountingBackup" directory. Then he opened Database manager and restored bobspizza.sqlite as current database.

Chrome asks for permission of public storage to download file (balance.pdf). It's seems that this file will be accessible to other applications that have permission to the storage, but Chrome does it delicate - it "hides, passes to the PDF-viewer then deletes" downloaded file, so you can't find it (file) in the storage. Maybe Chrome does it more properly (for files that has default application) - it uses private storage to downloads PDF then passes it to the viewer.
